the World Bank Group CIO I don't think I ever could have envisioned this day especially not speaking to 7500 people

here many of you have heard of the World Bank but many of you don't know what we
actually do we are not a bank in the very traditional sense of the word we
don't give people mortgages we don't hold consumer checking accounts rather we're an organization that was founded

member countries today 71 years later we have 189 member
countries and like the evolution of our shareholder base our mission has moved
as well the end of the mid 1970s we had all but reconstructed Europe and Japan and
so we pivoted our organization to look at the poorer countries and today we are
one of the largest sources of assistance to countries who support the poorest of
the poor and we do that through five subsidiaries working with both the public and the private
sector so I was excited to become the World Bank CIO but when I took the job I
realized the organization had spent the better part of the last 10 years not
investing in technology nothing really worked well everything
was kind of bubblegum and shoestringed together to give you a sense we had a
17-year-old on premise heavily customized email system and the worst
part about it was we weren't helping those end users those World Bank Group staff who live in and travel to some of
the most difficult and hardto-reach countries on Earth just last year alone
our staff made 250,000 trips oftentimes to countries
where connectivity is extremely poor this came honestly to light for me
about six months into my time as the World Bank CIO i went to Mongolia to

Stephanie would you like to see our modern operations portal in action and I said 'Well yeah sure show me how it
works so she booted up the application we went to lunch she came back and it
was still loading the 800 fields of data from our FE our systems of record in
Washington DC and that's when I said to myself we have a really serious problem
and we need to change the way we give our staff information in a novel and
innovative way we needed to make it available anytime anywhere and from any
device now about this same time the current president of the World Bank Jim
Kim became the president and he came into the bank with two really audacious
goals the first was to alleviate poverty by
2030 that means making sure that no one in the world lives on less than a$125 a
day the second audacious goal was to create shared prosperity and by shared
prosperity he meant taking the bottom 40% in any country and continuing to
lift them up so they never fall back into abject poverty so I said to Jim "This is really
great these are wonderful audacious goals we're never going to get there with the technology that we have today
we need modern technology and technology that's fit for purpose now luckily for
me Jim is a bit of a techie himself he understood what I was asking for and he
gave us the green light to go ahead so my team and I sat down and we created
a very detailed very innovative strategy tied very closely to those twin
goals but when we took a step back we said to ourselves "This is incredible
vision but without the right implementation plan we're never going to make this a reality." So we've spent the
last three and a half years executing on that plan we have ripped out and
upgraded almost every single application and platform in the bank and we've completely changed the technology

to a DC centric heavily customized application answering those
questions required us to rethink the connectivity we provided to our country

and we really knew we needed to create a renaissance in IT at the World Bank
Group but having a cloud first strategy and having cloud first as a pillar in
